results.title: Palace Cafe
results.creator_credit: Andrew Lancaster, Murray Fahey and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The Palace Cafe, a place where solitary drinkers sip their cappuccinos, read their newspapers and nothing much else happens. The cafe becomes alive one night when a lonely man spots an attractive woman across the room and staff and patrons burst into dance, choreographing their moves to the tune of the lonely man’s imagination.

results.title: Pal Joey
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Fred Kohlmar, George Sidney Productions and Essex
results.brief_description: Pal Joey, starring Frank Sinatra, Kim Novak and Rita Hayworth, is strong, funny entertainment based on a novel by John O’Hara. It features 14 songs from Rodgers and Hart including “The Lady is a Tramp”, “Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered” and “My Funny Valentine”. Sinatra is an out of heel nightclub singer, Joey Evans, who plays the field with women. He is ideal as the irreverent, glib Joey.

results.title: Pakistan: a two-part nation
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Talbot Isaacs and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: A study of East and West Pakistan, this film views the problems which arise from differences in people, geography and economy, between the two. Amidst uncertainty that threatens progress, the two Pakistans are held together by their religious tie of Islam.

results.title: Paisa
results.creator_credit: Roberto Rossellini, Foreign Film Productions and Organizzazione Film Internazionali
results.brief_description: Spoken in Italian dialogue with English subtitles. Covering the period from the Allied landings in Sicily in 1943 to the Liberation in 1945, Paisa is a film in six episodes. Each deals with a different aspect of the war in Italy; from the personal, (a drunken G.I. visits a prostitute and fails to recognise her as the young girl with whom he’d fallen in love only months earlier), to the field of battle itself, (brutal partisan warfare in Florence and the marshlands of the Po Delta). Following on from “Rome, Open City”, this was Rossellini’s second great neo-realist work and is one of the peak’s of film history. Stars Carmela Sazio, Robert Ban Loon, Dots M. Johnson, Maria Michi, Gar Moore, Harriet White, Renzo Avanzo, Bill Tubbs, Dale Edmonds.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Rossellini, Foreign Film Productions and Organizzazione Film Internazionali

results.title: Paintings need care
results.brief_description: English version by J.L. Levi-Alvares. Set to the background music of Handel, J.C.Bach and Vivaldi, this film illustrates how paintings stored in the National Museum of Warsaw which have been damaged by time or during wartime occupation of Poland, are restored. It shows the careful and painstaking skills required to once again allow these paintings to take their rightful place on the walls of the Museum.

results.creator_credit: H Tyrlova, K Hutecka and Kratky Film
results.brief_description: An animated film in which a mother brush and a father brush paint a baby brush and defend it against an ugly bad brush. No commentary, music only.

results.title: Painting with flowers
results.brief_description: Constance Spry, famous over the world for her knowledge of floral arrangements, speaks about the beauty of flowers in the home and stresses that arrangements are not difficult and can be done with very simple vessels. We see a number of demonstrations for a variety of places in the home including wall decorations.

results.title: Painting with calligraphy
results.creator_credit: Eliot O'Hara and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The history of calligraphy - or picture writing - in art is traced from prehistoric times to the present day. Varied used of calligraphy are shown in demonstrations by Eliot O’Hara, George Post, and Paul Travis, and in examples from the works of Burchfield, Dufy, Klee, Marin and Van Gogh.
